author: Ian Miles Cheong; August ; News
title: Secret Service agent leaves post to breastfeed before Trump rally - Rebel News
text: Secret Service agent leaves post to breastfeed before Trump rally The incident raises questions about security protocols at Trump's events. A Secret Service agent responsible for overseeing security at a recent rally for former President Donald Trump in North Carolina temporarily abandoned her post to breastfeed her child, according to a report by the [Daily Mail](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13747173/donald-trump-secret-service-investigation-breastfeed-child.html). The site agent, who had traveled from the Atlanta Field Office, was discovered in a room designated for "official work" just minutes before Trump's motorcade was due to arrive. The agent was reportedly accompanied by two family members in the restricted area. ðŸš¨ðŸš¨EXCLUSIVE and BREAKING: During a Donald Trump visit to North Carolina yesterday, a woman Secret Service special agent abandoned her post to breastfeed with no permission/warning to the event site agent, according to three sources in the Secret Service community.â€” Susan Crabtree (@susancrabtree) Shortlyâ€¦ [pic.twitter.com/lkfhhLcA0B] [August 15, 2024] Sources familiar with the incident claim that the agent and her family were escorted to the room by an unauthorized staff member, bypassing standard security checkpoints. This breach of protocol has raised concerns about adherence to security measures at high-profile political events. Secret Service spokesman Anthony Guglielmi addressed the situation, stating, "All employees of the U.S. Secret Service are held to the highest standards." He assured that the incident did not impact the North Carolina event but confirmed that the specifics are under examination. Guglielmi declined further comment, citing the matter as a personnel issue. This security lapse comes just over a month after a serious incident at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, where an assassination attempt resulted in the former president being grazed by a bullet in the ear. This security breach had already intensified scrutiny of the Secret Service's preparedness for such events. In the aftermath of the Pennsylvania incident, former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on July 23, following mounting external pressure. The latest occurrence in North Carolina is likely to fuel ongoing discussions about security measures and protocols surrounding the protection of high-profile political figures. - By Drea Humphrey [](https://www.rebelnews.com/tags/jonathan_yaniv) Jonathan 'Jessica' Yaniv Stay up to date and follow along as Rebel News's Drea Humphrey keeps tabs on the latest drama involving Jonathan 'Jessica' Yaniv. [Take Action](https://www.rebelnews.com/tags/jonathan_yaniv) Don't Get Censored Big Tech is censoring us. Sign up so we can always stay in touch. Don't Get Censored Big Tech is censoring us. author: sbs.com.au
title: How a $78 charity donation got this woman jailed for 12 years | SBS News
text:
Key Points Ksenia Karelina transferred $78 in February 2022 to a charity providing humanitarian aid to people in Ukraine. The 33-year-old dual citizen was arrested in early 2024 when she returned to Russia using her US passport. The Los Angeles resident has now pleaded guilty to treason charges at her trial in Russia. A Russian court has sentenced dual Russian-American citizen Ksenia Karelina to 12 years in prison after finding her guilty of treason for donating money to a charity supporting Ukraine.
The Los Angeles resident, a spa worker, pleaded guilty at her closed trial in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg, where her case was heard by the same court that convicted Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich of espionage in July.
The court said investigators found that on 24 February 2022 â€” the first day of Russia's invasion of Ukraine â€” Karelina had "transferred funds in the interests of a Ukrainian organisation, which were subsequently used for the purchase of tactical medicine items, equipment, means of defeat and ammunition by the Armed Forces of Ukraine".
Her supporters say she had donated US$51.80 ($78) to Razom for Ukraine, a New York-based charity that provides humanitarian aid to children and elderly people in Ukraine.
READ MORE How far have Ukrainian troops pushed into Russia and where are they?
The charity has denied it provides any military support to Kyiv.
Karelina, 33, appeared in court on Thursday in a white sweatshirt and blue jeans, sitting calmly in a glass courtroom cage.
She was not included in a major prisoner swap between Russia and the West two weeks ago that freed journalist Evan Gershkovich , but her lawyer, Mikhail Mushailov, has said she hoped to be included in a future exchange.
Karelina was born in Russia and emigrated to the United States in 2012 via a work-study program, receiving American citizenship in 2021.
She was arrested by the FSB security service after flying to Russia to visit her family in Yekaterinburg at the start of 2024.
Problems began immediately for Karelina when she arrived in Russia using her US passport.
Karelina's lawyer said she hoped she could be included in a future prisoner swap between Russia and the West. Source: EPA / AAP Authorities interrogated her and took her mobile phone on which they found the 2022 donation to the charity, Razom for Ukraine, on her Venmo account, according to the website freeksenia.com.
The FSB interrogated her during weekly check-ins and banned her from leaving the city, the website says.
Three days before she was due to return to Los Angeles, Karelina was arrested on a hooliganism charges and jailed for 15 days.
Just before her release, she was slapped with a state treason charge.
READ MORE Inside the Russia-West prisoner swap: Here's who was exchanged in the major deal
Karelina's family and friends in the US have described her as someone who did not much care for politics and said they were shocked by her arrest.
Her boyfriend, Christopher van Heerden, told Reuters he had been in contact with the State Department and the US embassy in Moscow about securing her release.
Unlike in the cases of Gershkovich and former US Marine Paul Whelan, who was also freed in the swap in August, Karelina has not been designated by Washington as "wrongfully detained", a label that would open up diplomatic avenues to negotiate a prisoner exchange.

organizations.name: sbs news key points ksenia karelina

author: Angel Saunders
title: Thieves Nicknamed 'Ms. Dookie' and 'Mr. Clean' Distracted Dollar Store Employees with Poop to Steal Cleaning Supplies, Police Say
text:
Tina Joyce and Nikevee Curry were named as suspects in the December incident
By Angel Saunders Angel Saunders Angel Saunders has been a writer at PEOPLE since 2023. Sheâ€™s previously worked at iHeartMedia, IndieWire, and REVOLT. People Editorial Guidelines Published on March 12, 2025 09:06PM EDT Comments Tina Joyce; Nikevee Curry. Photo: Polk County Sheriff's Office (2)
A woman allegedly defecated in a store to distract employees while her alleged male accomplice stole items as part of a bizarre theft , authorities say.
The Polk County Sheriffâ€™s Office shared an X post in January, detailing the incident that took place around noon on Dec. 18, 2024 at a Family Dollar store at 2170 Bailey Road in Mulberry, Fla.
The suspects, later identified as Tina Joyce and Nikevee Curry, â€œplayed different roles as they conspired in their retail theft. Very different roles,â€ the Jan. 9 post read.
4 People Accused of Using Bear Costume to Damage Cars in Elaborate Insurance Fraud According to the PCSO, Curry, 36, allegedly stole $500 worth of cleaning products such as â€œGain, Tide, and Clorox productsâ€ while Joyce, 57, â€œcaused a distraction for employees by using the restroom...without going to the restroom. The floor was her restroom. And an employee had to clean that...stuff up.â€
Nikevee Curry. Polk County Sheriff's Office
â€œWe....kid you not,â€ the post continued.
The PCSO added that the woman left the Family Dollar store in a white Ford van.
â€˜Haggler After Midnight,' Who Negotiates What Heâ€™ll Steal from Victims, Sought by New York City Police They were dubbed by the department as "Mr. Clean" and "Ms. Dookie."
Video showed the suspects roaming the store separately, with Curry appearing on surveillance footage pushing a shopping cart full of merchandise. Moments later, Joyce was seen walking in the same direction.
Hashtags included in the Polk County Sheriffâ€™s Office tweet said â€œ #HeMadeACleanGetaway ,â€ while noting â€œ #SheCantReallySayTheSame .â€
Tina Joyce. Polk County Sheriff's Office
The sheriffâ€™s office also stated â€œ #SheWasntSuspectNumberTwoForNothing .â€
Joyce was arrested and charged with felony petit theft on Feb. 18 before she was released on $5,000 bail Feb. 28. Curry, who was previously arrested for theft and parole violation in 2023, is still wanted in connection with the alleged crime.
Want to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.
Curry was also arrested for battery by the Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office on Dec. 21, 2024, where he remains in custody.
A spokesperson for the Polk County Sheriffâ€™s Office tells PEOPLE, â€œOnce heâ€™s released from there, he should be delivered to Polk County.â€
